metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Analyse the photoelectric effect with reference to: evidence for the particle-like nature of light; experimental data in the form of graphs of photocurrent versus electrode potential, and of kinetic energy of electrons versus frequency; kinetic energy of emitted photoelectrons: Ek max = hf ‚àí œÜ, using energy units of joule and electron-volt; effects of intensity of incident irradiation on the emission of photoelectrons

photoelectric_definition.name: Photoelectric Effect Definition
photoelectric_definition.correct: The photoelectric effect is light causing electrons to be ejected from a metal surface when the light frequency exceeds the threshold.

electrons emitting light.error: Direction reversed. Light causes electron emission, not vice versa.
electrons emitting light.fix: Light provides energy TO electrons, enabling them to escape the metal.
electrons emitting light.action: Think: photon hits metal ‚Üí electron leaves. Not electron ‚Üí light.

any light ejects electrons.error: Frequency matters. Only light above threshold frequency works.
any light ejects electrons.fix: Each metal has a minimum frequency. Below it, no electrons are emitted regardless of intensity.
any light ejects electrons.action: Red light on zinc does nothing. UV light ejects electrons. Why?

heat causes emission.error: Confusing photoelectric effect with thermionic emission.
heat causes emission.fix: Photoelectric effect is caused by light frequency, not heat.
heat causes emission.action: Photoelectric = light. Thermionic = heat. Different mechanisms.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what causes photoelectron emission.
persistent.action: Review: Light of sufficient frequency hits metal ‚Üí photon absorbed ‚Üí electron gains energy ‚Üí electron escapes if energy exceeds work function.

threshold_frequency.name: Threshold Frequency
threshold_frequency.correct: The threshold frequency is the minimum frequency of light needed to eject electrons from a specific metal surface.

maximum frequency.error: Opposite. It's the minimum, not maximum.
maximum frequency.fix: Below threshold = no emission. Above threshold = emission occurs.
maximum frequency.action: Think of a door requiring minimum force to open. Threshold frequency is that minimum.

same for all metals.error: Each metal has its own threshold frequency.
same for all metals.fix: Threshold frequency depends on work function, which varies by metal.
same for all metals.action: Compare: zinc needs UV, caesium needs visible light. Different thresholds.

depends on intensity.error: Threshold frequency is independent of light intensity.
depends on intensity.fix: Brighter light doesn't change the threshold. Only frequency matters.
depends on intensity.action: A dim UV source can eject electrons from zinc; bright red light cannot.

persistent.gap: You're confusing threshold frequency with other photoelectric variables.
persistent.action: Memorise: f‚ÇÄ = œÜ/h. Each metal has unique œÜ, therefore unique f‚ÇÄ. Intensity doesn't affect it.

work_function.name: Work Function
work_function.correct: The work function is the minimum energy required to release the most loosely bound electron from a metal surface.

energy of all electrons.error: Work function is for the MOST loosely bound electron only.
energy of all electrons.fix: Other electrons need MORE energy to escape. Work function is the minimum.
energy of all electrons.action: Some electrons are deeper in the metal. They need more than œÜ to escape.

energy of incident light.error: Work function is a property of the metal, not the light.
energy of incident light.fix: Light has energy hf. Work function œÜ is what the metal 'demands' from that energy.
energy of incident light.action: Same metal has same œÜ regardless of light source.

kinetic energy of electrons.error: Work function is used UP escaping. It doesn't become kinetic energy.
kinetic energy of electrons.fix: KE = hf ‚àí œÜ. The work function is subtracted, not added.
kinetic energy of electrons.action: œÜ goes to breaking free. Only leftover energy (hf ‚àí œÜ) becomes KE.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding that work function is a metal property, not an electron energy.
persistent.action: Think of œÜ as a 'fee' to leave the metal. Each metal charges a different fee.

stopping_potential.name: Stopping Potential
stopping_potential.correct: The stopping potential is the minimum reverse voltage needed to stop the most energetic photoelectrons, giving their maximum kinetic energy in eV.

accelerating voltage.error: Stopping potential opposes electron motion, it doesn't accelerate them.
accelerating voltage.fix: It's a reverse (retarding) potential that stops the fastest electrons.
accelerating voltage.action: Positive collector attracts electrons. Negative collector repels them.

voltage at maximum current.error: Stopping potential is where current reaches zero, not maximum.
voltage at maximum current.fix: At V‚ÇÄ, even the fastest electrons can't reach the collector.
voltage at maximum current.action: Read the graph: V‚ÇÄ is where photocurrent = 0.

work function in volts.error: Stopping potential measures kinetic energy, not work function.
work function in volts.fix: V‚ÇÄ = KEmax/e. Work function appears on the energy-frequency graph as the y-intercept.
work function in volts.action: From I-V graph: read V‚ÇÄ. From KE-f graph: read œÜ from y-intercept.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding how stopping potential relates to electron energy.
persistent.action: Key relationship: KEmax (in eV) = V‚ÇÄ (in V). Numerically equal.

intensity_effect.name: Effect of Intensity
intensity_effect.correct: Increasing light intensity increases the number of photoelectrons (photocurrent) but does not change their maximum kinetic energy.

increases kinetic energy.error: Intensity affects electron number, not energy.
increases kinetic energy.fix: Each photon has energy hf regardless of how many photons there are.
increases kinetic energy.action: More photons = more electrons. Same energy per photon = same KEmax.

decreases threshold frequency.error: Threshold frequency is independent of intensity.
decreases threshold frequency.fix: Threshold frequency depends only on the metal (work function).
decreases threshold frequency.action: Bright red light still won't eject electrons from zinc. Frequency too low.

changes stopping potential.error: Stopping potential depends on frequency, not intensity.
changes stopping potential.fix: V‚ÇÄ = KEmax/e. KEmax depends on frequency only.
changes stopping potential.action: Double the intensity, same V‚ÇÄ. Double the frequency, higher V‚ÇÄ.

persistent.gap: You're conflating intensity effects with frequency effects.
persistent.action: Intensity = number of photons. Frequency = energy per photon. Different roles.

frequency_effect.name: Effect of Frequency
frequency_effect.correct: Increasing light frequency increases the maximum kinetic energy of photoelectrons but does not change the maximum photocurrent.

increases photocurrent.error: Number of electrons depends on intensity, not frequency.
increases photocurrent.fix: Higher frequency gives MORE energy per electron, not more electrons.
increases photocurrent.action: Same intensity, higher frequency: same current, higher stopping voltage.

decreases work function.error: Work function is a metal property, independent of light.
decreases work function.fix: The metal doesn't change when you change the light frequency.
decreases work function.action: œÜ is fixed for a given metal. Changing frequency changes hf, not œÜ.

no effect on kinetic energy.error: KEmax = hf ‚àí œÜ shows direct dependence on frequency.
no effect on kinetic energy.fix: Higher f means higher hf, so more energy left over as kinetic energy.
no effect on kinetic energy.action: Calculate: KEmax at 6√ó10¬π‚Å¥ Hz vs 8√ó10¬π‚Å¥ Hz. See the difference.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting frequency to photon energy and electron kinetic energy.
persistent.action: Chain: f ‚Üë ‚Üí hf ‚Üë ‚Üí (hf ‚àí œÜ) ‚Üë ‚Üí KEmax ‚Üë ‚Üí V‚ÇÄ ‚Üë

ke_frequency_graph.name: KE-Frequency Graph Features
ke_frequency_graph.correct: The KE-frequency graph is linear with gradient equal to Planck's constant, x-intercept at threshold frequency, and y-intercept at negative work function.

gradient equals work function.error: Gradient equals Planck's constant h, not work function.
gradient equals work function.fix: Compare to y = mx + c: gradient m = h, intercept c = ‚àíœÜ.
gradient equals work function.action: Calculate gradient from graph: rise/run gives h ‚âà 4.14 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Åµ eV¬∑s.

x-intercept equals work function.error: X-intercept is threshold frequency f‚ÇÄ, not work function.
x-intercept equals work function.fix: At KEmax = 0: hf‚ÇÄ = œÜ, so f‚ÇÄ = œÜ/h. The x-intercept is f‚ÇÄ.
x-intercept equals work function.action: Work function appears at y-intercept (as negative value), not x-intercept.

curved relationship.error: The relationship is linear, not curved.
curved relationship.fix: KEmax = hf ‚àí œÜ is a straight line equation.
curved relationship.action: Plot some points: same gradient h for all metals, different intercepts.

persistent.gap: You're not reading KE-f graphs correctly.
persistent.action: Practice: gradient = h, x-intercept = f‚ÇÄ, y-intercept = ‚àíœÜ.

einstein_equation.name: Einstein's Photoelectric Equation
einstein_equation.correct: Einstein's equation shows that maximum kinetic energy equals photon energy minus work function.

KEmax = hf + œÜ.error: Work function is subtracted, not added.
KEmax = hf + œÜ.fix: Energy is conserved: hf = œÜ + KEmax, so KEmax = hf ‚àí œÜ.
KEmax = hf + œÜ.action: Think: photon energy pays the work function 'fee', leftover is KE.

KEmax = œÜ ‚àí hf.error: Order is reversed. Photon energy is larger.
KEmax = œÜ ‚àí hf.fix: If hf < œÜ, no emission. If hf > œÜ, the excess is KEmax.
KEmax = œÜ ‚àí hf.action: Would give negative KE when hf > œÜ. That's impossible.

KEmax = hf/œÜ.fix: Energy conservation: input energy = work done + output energy.
KEmax = hf/œÜ.action: Check units: eV ‚àí eV = eV. Division would give a unitless number.

persistent.gap: You need to understand the energy conservation in the photoelectric effect.
persistent.action: Diagram: hf (in) ‚Üí œÜ (to escape) + KEmax (leftover). Always subtraction.

photon_energy_formula.name: Photon Energy
photon_energy_formula.correct: Photon energy equals Planck's constant times frequency, or equivalently Planck's constant times speed of light divided by wavelength.

E = hŒª.error: Energy is inversely proportional to wavelength, not directly.
E = hŒª.fix: E = hc/Œª. Longer wavelength means LESS energy.
E = hŒª.action: Red light (long Œª) has less energy than blue light (short Œª).

E = f/h.error: Planck's constant multiplies frequency, not divides.
E = f/h.fix: E = hf. The constant h scales the frequency to energy.

E = mc¬≤.error: That's mass-energy equivalence, not photon energy.
E = mc¬≤.fix: Photons have no rest mass. Use E = hf for photon energy.
E = mc¬≤.action: E = mc¬≤ is for rest mass. Photons use E = hf = pc.

persistent.gap: You're not remembering the photon energy formula correctly.
persistent.action: Memorise: E = hf = hc/Œª. Higher f (or lower Œª) means more energy.

wave_model_failure_time.name: Wave Model Failure: Time Delay
wave_model_failure_time.correct: The wave model predicted a time delay for energy accumulation, but photoelectrons are emitted almost instantaneously.

wave model predicted instant emission.error: Wave model predicted gradual energy absorption, requiring time.
wave model predicted instant emission.fix: Waves spread energy continuously. Should take time to accumulate enough.
wave model predicted instant emission.action: Wave model: dim light ‚Üí slow energy buildup ‚Üí delayed emission.

photoelectric effect shows time delay.error: No measurable time delay is observed experimentally.
photoelectric effect shows time delay.fix: Electrons are emitted within 10‚Åª‚Åπ seconds, effectively instantaneous.
photoelectric effect shows time delay.action: Particle model explains: one photon delivers ALL its energy at once.

time delay depends on frequency.error: Time delay was predicted for low intensity, not related to frequency.
time delay depends on frequency.fix: Wave model issue was dim light needing time, regardless of frequency.
time delay depends on frequency.action: Even dim light above threshold causes instant emission. No delay.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding what the wave model incorrectly predicted.
persistent.action: Wave model predicted: continuous energy transfer ‚Üí time needed. Observation: instant.

wave_model_failure_threshold.name: Wave Model Failure: Threshold Frequency
wave_model_failure_threshold.formula: Observed: f < f‚ÇÄ gives no emission
wave_model_failure_threshold.correct: The wave model predicted any frequency should eventually eject electrons with enough intensity, but a threshold frequency exists below which no emission occurs regardless of intensity.

wave model predicted threshold.error: Wave model predicted NO threshold. Any frequency should work.
wave model predicted threshold.fix: Continuous energy delivery should allow any frequency to eventually emit electrons.
wave model predicted threshold.action: Wave model: bright red light should eventually emit electrons. It doesn't.

threshold depends on intensity.error: Threshold frequency is independent of intensity.
threshold depends on intensity.fix: Threshold is determined by metal's work function and Planck's constant only.
threshold depends on intensity.action: No amount of red light ejects electrons from zinc. Frequency too low.

particle model can't explain threshold.fix: Each photon needs energy hf ‚â• œÜ. Below threshold, individual photons lack energy.
particle model can't explain threshold.action: One photon, one electron. If photon energy < œÜ, electron can't escape.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the threshold frequency contradiction.
persistent.action: Wave: any f should work with enough intensity. Particle: need hf ‚â• œÜ per photon.

wave_model_failure_intensity.name: Wave Model Failure: Intensity and KE
wave_model_failure_intensity.correct: The wave model predicted higher intensity should increase electron kinetic energy, but KEmax depends only on frequency.

wave model predicted no intensity effect.error: Wave model predicted MORE intensity = MORE energy per electron.
wave model predicted no intensity effect.fix: Brighter wave should transfer more energy, increasing KEmax. It doesn't.
wave model predicted no intensity effect.action: Wave model: louder = more energy delivered. Light doesn't work that way.

intensity does affect kinetic energy.error: Experiments show KEmax is independent of intensity.
intensity does affect kinetic energy.fix: Intensity affects NUMBER of electrons, not their ENERGY.
intensity does affect kinetic energy.action: Double intensity: double photocurrent, same stopping potential.

particle model can't explain intensity i.fix: More intensity = more photons, each with same energy hf.
particle model can't explain intensity i.action: Each photon gives hf energy. More photons doesn't change hf per photon.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing what intensity affects vs what frequency affects.
persistent.action: Intensity ‚Üí number of electrons. Frequency ‚Üí energy per electron.

electron_volt_conversion.name: Electron-Volt Conversion
electron_volt_conversion.correct: One electron-volt equals 1.6 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Åπ joules, the energy gained by an electron accelerated through 1 volt.

persistent.action: 1 eV = 1.6 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Åπ J. eV is smaller. To convert J ‚Üí eV, divide.

planck_constant_value.name: Planck's Constant

d6.tooltip: Particle behavior appears during absorption and emission.
